overview.short: Spirillum species are Gram-negative, aerobic spiral-shaped bacteria with polar flagella, most often encountered in aquatic environments.
overview.clinical_context: Rarely implicated in human disease; primarily environmental organisms and occasional opportunists in unusual exposures.

field_notes.Shape: Spiral morphology is characteristic; curved rods may require differentiation from Campylobacter-like organisms.
field_notes.Oxygen Requirement: Generally aerobic; poor/variable growth may occur on routine plates without enriched or aquatic-adapted conditions.
field_notes.Sugar Fermentation: Typically non-fermentative; carbohydrate reactions are expected to be negative.

key_differentiators.notes: True spiral morphology supports Spirillum over straight rods or comma-shaped curved rods.
Oxidase positivity supports non-Enterobacterales environmental spirals.
Non-fermentative profile supports Spirillum over many oxidase-positive fermenters.

common_confusions.reason: Both can appear curved/spiral and oxidase positive; Campylobacter is typically microaerophilic and has different growth temperature patterns.
Both may appear spiral; Helicobacter is typically microaerophilic and urease-positive (species-dependent), with different clinical context.
Comma-shaped curved rods may be mistaken for spirals; Vibrio commonly ferments glucose and often has NaCl-related growth traits.

when_to_question_identification: Glucose fermentation positivity argues against Spirillum.
Requirement for microaerophilic conditions suggests Campylobacter or Helicobacter rather than Spirillum.
Strong growth in high salt (>=6% NaCl) suggests halophiles (e.g., Vibrio) rather than Spirillum.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Useful for characterising non-fermentative, oxidase-positive environmental isolates.
Confirms strong polar flagellar motility and spiral morphology.
Recommended due to rarity and limited resolution of routine biochemical panels for Spirillum.
